key_points: Donald Rumsfeld, former U.S. Secretary of Defense, died at the age of 88 from multiple myeloma.
Rumsfeld's career was marked by his roles in the George W. Bush administration, particularly his management of the Middle East wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.
He served as the U.S. Secretary of Defense twice, first under President Gerald Ford and then under President George W. Bush.
Rumsfeld was known for his involvement in post-9/11 military conflicts and the administration's contentious policies and strategies in the Middle East.
He was criticized for the handling of the military conflicts, including matters related to the search for weapons of mass destruction and reports of detainee abuses.
After leaving politics, Rumsfeld focused on various projects, including writing a memoir, participating in a documentary, and launching a mobile game.
Rumsfeld maintained that removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq was justified, despite later admissions of faulty intelligence.
President George W. Bush remembered Rumsfeld for his service and dedication following the attacks on September 11, 2001.
Documentarian Errol Morris described Rumsfeld as somewhat 'clueless' after spending 33 hours interviewing him for a documentary.
The Rumsfeld family highlighted his love for his wife, family, friends, and his dedication to public service in their statement announcing his death.
